title: 107_hr4141
content: The Act is titled the "Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act defines the terms "Corporation" as The Howard Hughes Corporation and "Red Rock" as the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area in Nevada. The Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area in Clark County, Nevada, spans 195,780 acres and is protected under the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act of 1990. The area is depicted on the Red Rock Map, dated July 1, 2002, and overseen by the Secretary of the Interior. The Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area in Clark County, Nevada, is protected under the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act of 1990. The area is overseen by the Secretary of the Interior. The Congress recognizes Red Rock as a significant natural resource that must be protected for future generations. The Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998 aimed to enhance and protect Red Rock. The Corporation owns land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is involved in development efforts. The Corporation owns 1,071 acres of high-ground lands at the eastern edge of Red Rock, intended for inclusion in the protected area but not yet acquired by the United States. The Corporation has volunteered to forgo development of the high-ground lands and proposes that the United States acquire title to preserve the important view-shed of the western Las Vegas Valley. The Corporation owns high-ground acreage in the western Las Vegas Valley view-shed and has volunteered to forgo development. They propose the United States acquire the lands to preserve them in perpetuity for the protection and expansion of Red Rock through a land exchange. The Corporation has volunteered to forgo development of high-ground acreage in the western Las Vegas Valley view-shed to protect and expand Red Rock through a land exchange with the United States. The Act aims to exchange lands to transfer high-ground lands to the United States and protect Red Rock as depicted on the Red Rock Map, fulfilling the purposes of the Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998. The Corporation offers to convey approximately 1,082 acres of nonfederal land to the United States for incorporation into NCA. The Secretary will accept the offer and make conveyances within 90 days, including transferring approximately 998 acres of Federal lands to the Corporation and approximately 1,221 acres to Clark County, Nevada. The United States will convey approximately 998 acres of Federal lands to the Corporation and approximately 1,221 acres to Clark County, Nevada within 90 days. The conveyances will be simultaneous, and the Secretary will keep the Red Rock Map on file. The Secretary will convey Federal lands to the Corporation and Clark County, Nevada simultaneously. The Red Rock Map will be kept on file for public inspection. The Bureau of Land Management in Nevada and Reno, Nevada have documents available for public inspection. Conditions for conveyance include the Corporation being responsible for hazardous materials removal and remediation. A survey must be conducted within 90 days of the offer. The Secretary requires that lands transferred to Clark County must be held in perpetuity for use as a public park or regional trail system. The Act allows for technical corrections to the Red Rock Map and the withdrawal of affected lands from public land and mining laws, subject to valid existing rights. The Secretary shall withdraw Federal lands acquired or owned by the United States under the Act from public land and mining laws, subject to valid existing rights. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 1, 2002.
